samples.question: Why did you choose to study this subject?

samples.question: Do you do any exercise?
samples.transcript: Yeah, sure. From time to time. What kind? Well, I try to go to the gym once or twice a week. and I like going for walks in the evening when it is a bit cooler.

samples.question: What kind of weather do you like best?
samples.transcript: Rainy weather, definitely. Why? Oh, because it rarely rains in my region, so when it does, everyone is really happy. And it cools down the temperature too.

samples.question: Do other people like this building?
samples.transcript: Yes, everyone likes it. it is a real landmark of the city now.

samples.question: Which one is more important?
samples.transcript: Well, I would have to say both. first of all, of course, the government should try to maintain traditional buildings, they are our, our heritage, and, they connect us to a past, in, in a way that looking at a photo in a book cannot. Personally, I do not enjoy looking around old buildings such as castles, but I know in some countries tourists flock to these type of buildings. So I can imagine that many people in those countries want to see them preserved. But on the other hand we shouldn be spending so much money on them that we have poor health and education service Educating our children and treating sick people has to be a priority too And is it possible for a government to fund all of these things?

Um, first of all, of course, the government should try to maintain traditional buildings, um, they are our, our heritage, and, uh, they connect us to a past, uh, in, in a way that looking at a photo in a book cannot. Personally, I don't enjoy looking around old buildings such as castles, but I know in some countries tourists flock to these type of buildings. So I can imagine that many people in those countries want to see them preserved. But on the other hand we shouldn be spending so much money on them that we have poor health and education service Educating our children and treating sick people has to be a priority too And is it possible for a government to fund all of these things?

samples.question: Can a government pay for all of these things?
samples.transcript: Well, I suppose it depends on the country. My country is fairly wealthy, so yes, I think it can afford public services and money for preservation. But in poorer countries, I can imagine that the majority of people there would want better schools and good hospitals. Many people like living in modern buildings.

samples.question: Why do you think that is?
samples.transcript: Well, I think I am one of them. living in a modern home is much easier on the whole, I think. You do not have to worry about, what is the word, you know, fixing them up all the time. Oh, renovating. that is it. You do not have to renovate new homes. they are in perfect condition. And this probably saves a lot of money. I imagine repairing and maintaining a home is very costly. And, another reason, of course, is that modern homes have all the mod cons, you know, modern conveniences. And I think most people these days are looking for ways to save time.

samples.question: Homes in the future?
samples.transcript: That is a good question. Let me see. If you mean ten or twenty years from now, I do not think they will be that different to what we have now. But perhaps fifty years from now, I think it is likely that we will see some changes. I think cities will get denser than they are now. Now, I mean, there'll be more people living in the same area. To cope with this, I think homes will get, smaller and perhaps taller, in order to fit more people in. In the major cities in my country, this has already happened. But fifty years from now, I think most cities and towns will be the same. Very, dense. Well, thank you very much.
samples.transcript_original: That's a good question. Let me see. If you mean ten or twenty years from now, I don't think they will be that different to what we have now.
